snippet: Thousands of Vietnamese workers rampaged after China placed an oil rig in disputed waters, but most of the factories hit were owned by companies from South Korea and Taiwan.
abstract: Thousands of Vietnamese workers rampage, setting fire to dozens of foreign-owned factories after China places an oil rig in disputed waters off Vietnam's coast without warning; riots mark a rare outpouring of popular outrage over China's increasingly insistent claims to strategically important, resource-rich seas; in their rage, however, Vietnamese workers appear to have misdirect their anger, attacking businesses from South Korea and Taiwan that took the risk of investing in their nation.

byline.original: By CHRIS BUCKLEY, CHAU DOAN and THOMAS FULLER
byline.contributor: Chris Buckley and Chau Doan reported from Binh Duong Province, Vietnam, and Thomas Fuller from Bangkok. Reporting was contributed by Keith Bradsher from Hong Kong; Choe Sang-hun from Seoul, South Korea; Austin Ramzy from Taipei, Taiwan; Mike Ives from Hanoi, Vietnam; and Rick Gladstone from New York. Bree Feng contributed research from Beijing.

lead_paragraph: Thousands of Vietnamese workers rampaged after China placed an oil rig in disputed waters, but most of the factories hit were owned by companies from South Korea and Taiwan.

headline.main: China Targeted by Vietnamese in Fiery Riots
